etymologies: Old English thrāwan ‘to twist, turn’, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch draaien and German drehen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin terere ‘to rub’, Greek teirein ‘wear out’. throw (sense 1 of the verb), expressing propulsion and sudden action, dates from Middle English

definitions: propel (something) with force through the air by a movement of the arm and hand

examples.text: I threw a brick through the window

notes.text: with object and usually with adverbial

shortDefinitions: propel something with force through air by movement of arm and hand

definitions: push or force (someone or something) violently and suddenly into a particular physical position or state

examples.text: the pilot and one passenger were thrown clear and survived
the door was thrown open and a uniformed guard entered the room

notes.text: with object and adverbial or complement

shortDefinitions: push or force person or thing violently

definitions: put in place or erect quickly

examples.text: the stewards had thrown a cordon across the fairway

shortDefinitions: put in place or erect quickly

definitions: move (a part of the body) quickly or suddenly in a particular direction

examples.text: she threw her head back and laughed

shortDefinitions: move part of body quickly or suddenly in particular direction

definitions: project or cast (light or shadow) in a particular direction

examples.text: a chandelier threw its bright light over the walls

shortDefinitions: project or cast light or shadow in particular direction

definitions: deliver (a punch)

examples.text: Cheryl drew back her fist and threw another punch

shortDefinitions: deliver

definitions: direct a particular kind of look or facial expression

examples.text: she threw a withering glance at him

shortDefinitions: direct particular kind of look or facial expression

definitions: project (one's voice) so that it appears to come from someone or something else, as in ventriloquism

examples.text: I can throw my voice—I could make a fortune as a medium

shortDefinitions: project one's voice so that it appears to come from person or thing else, as in ventriloquism

definitions: move (a switch or lever) so as to operate a device

examples.text: at the trolley portal the operator had to manually throw the switch using a switch iron

shortDefinitions: move switch or lever so as to operate device

definitions: roll (dice)

examples.text: he reached out and put the dice in the shaker and threw them

shortDefinitions: roll

definitions: obtain (a specified number) by rolling dice.
shortDefinitions: obtain specified number by rolling dice

definitions: (of a horse) lose (a shoe).
shortDefinitions: (of horse) lose

definitions: cause to enter suddenly a particular state or condition

examples.text: he threw all her emotions into turmoil
the bond market was thrown into confusion

shortDefinitions: send suddenly into particular state or condition

definitions: put (someone) in a particular place or state in a rough, abrupt, or summary fashion

examples.text: these guys should be thrown in jail

shortDefinitions: put someone in particular place or state in rough

definitions: disconcert; confuse

examples.text: she frowned, thrown by this apparent change of tack

shortDefinitions: disconcert

synonyms.text: cause someone to lose their composure

definitions: send (one's opponent) to the ground in wrestling, judo, or similar activity

examples.text: in the final Arnaud was too strong, and threw Hughes twice

shortDefinitions: send one's opponent to ground in wrestling, judo, or similar activity

definitions: (of a horse) unseat (its rider)

examples.text: their horse threw its jockey before the race had started

shortDefinitions: (of horse) unseat

definitions: form (ceramic ware) on a potter's wheel

examples.text: further on a potter was throwing pots

shortDefinitions: form ceramic ware on potter's wheel

definitions: turn (wood or other material) on a lathe.
shortDefinitions: turn wood or other material on lathe

definitions: twist (silk or other fabrics) into thread or yarn.
shortDefinitions: twist silk or other fabrics into thread or yarn

definitions: have (a fit or tantrum)

examples.text: occasionally a small child will throw a tantrum when denied something

shortDefinitions: have

definitions: give or hold (a party)

examples.text: he threw a huge farewell party for them

shortDefinitions: give or hold

definitions: lose (a race or contest) intentionally, especially in return for a bribe

examples.text: the man who throws a race is a crook for life

shortDefinitions: lose race intentionally

definitions: (of an animal) give birth to (young, especially of a specified kind)

examples.text: sometimes a completely black calf is thrown

shortDefinitions: (of animal) give birth to

definitions: an act of throwing something

examples.text: Jeter's throw to first base was too late

shortDefinitions: act of throwing something

definitions: an act of throwing one's opponent in wrestling, judo, or a similar sport

examples.text: a shoulder throw

shortDefinitions: act of throwing one's opponent in wrestling

crossReferenceMarkers: short for roll of the dice (see dice)

examples.text: this decision represents something of a final throw
people who hazard their entire company on one major throw

definitions: a light cover for furniture.
shortDefinitions: light cover for furniture

definitions: used to indicate how much a single item, turn, or attempt costs

examples.text: he was offering to draw on-the-spot portraits at $25 a throw

shortDefinitions: used to indicate how much single item, turn, or attempt costs

definitions: the extent of vertical displacement between the two sides of a fault.
shortDefinitions: extent of vertical displacement in fault

definitions: the action or motion, or the extent of such motion, of a slide valve, crank, eccentric wheel, or cam.
shortDefinitions: action or motion of slide valve or of crank, eccentric wheel, or cam

definitions: the distance moved by the pointer of an instrument.
shortDefinitions: distance moved by pointer of instrument
